sentences.sentence: By Neil SeemanOurs is the era of job discontent.
Amid an historic labour shortage and impending recession, is it disloyal to complain?
Plato believed one's identity should be bound to one's life work and to the pursuit of virtue.

In his view, work should demand the same level of philosophic self-examination as one's treatment of friends and family.The consolations of philosophic contemplation elude too many workers and job-seekers nowadays.
To achieve virtue, a devotee of Plato would ask: how can I do more for my employer?
Or how am I so lucky as to have a job that can produce goods of value for my community?

Today, these Platonic questions seem quaint.Were they with us in the 21st century, Plato's students might describe themselves very differently than modern job applicants, who prioritize, not virtue, but what the late business guru Clayton Christensen called the "hygiene factors" in employment: status, compensation and job security.Seek far more than personal fulfillment, Plato cautioned, lest you spiral into a never-ending cycle of discontent in your work.

Disciples of Plato might note on their LinkedIn resum√©s something more than just saying they are "open for work"; they might describe a dream job as "keeping the community safe" or "providing my family with food and clothing.
"In The Republic - Plato's conception of the ideal state - material personal gains and status were secondary to the foundational purpose of work.

Consider, first, Plato counselled, what your current work means to your family and community and how it can contribute to the greater good.Platonic workers attain empowerment by contemplating the deeper meaning of their work and how their work connects to what society may require in the future.
It is only after decades of hard work, claims Plato, that a person, finally possessed of some demonstrable knowledge of a just society, can be considered for a position of political power.

This experience-before-power trajectory lies in stark contrast to today's career politicians.Justice, in the eyes of Plato (voiced through the character of Socrates in The Republic), must always be relative to the needs of those who are served, not to the desires of those who serve them.

Accordingly, the just physician must be rewarded not by her rung in the medical hierarchy, but by her success in curing her patients.The Republic ends with a declaration from Socrates' character that only the just worker is truly happy, this being someone who aligns reason, sustenance, and spirituality in the pursuit of virtue.
The just worker is someone who prospers not merely in this life but "during the journey of a thousand years.
"Plato's view of work is idealistic.
For work, like life itself, is a world of light and shadows: the perfect job, the perfect employee, and the perfect company to work for don't really exist.
Workers who think about the value of their work recognize its limits.
Regardless of the limits, however, workers could, and perhaps should, still self-reflect on the value they bring to their less than ideal job.William Watson: Where have all the workers gone?

To time passing(https://financialpost.com/opinion/where-workers-gone-time-passing)Philip Cross: Face it, millennials: There is no realistic alternative to capitalism(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-no-realistic-alternative-to-capitalism)Opinion: Canadians are right to worry about immigration levels(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-canadians-are-right-to-worry-about-immigration-levels)By contrast, observations (often from survey data) about what is happening in the modern workplace tend to fixate on fads and superficial preferences.

Examples of such preferences might include employees' advocacy for less customer-facing travel or less teamwork, since, as this narrative goes, Gen Z and Millennial workers, in distinction to other generations of workers, crave the autonomy, solitude and flexibility they enjoyed during pandemic lockdowns.Preference is not virtue.
Preference is self-serving; virtue is community-serving.
It is a constant to strive for, recognizing that it can never be fully achieved.

A workplace is never perfect, but our role within it can be perfected.The goal of any job - and the goal of the tenacious entrepreneur who undertook financial risk to create that job for you - is to offer goods and services your community needs in order to fuel collective prosperity.
Plato, if you were to meet him face to face, would say: "be open to work hard" and "be open to self-reflection about what you bring to your job."
After committing to that, you may still be discontented, but it would be a virtuous discontent.Neil Seeman is a senior fellow at Massey College in the University of Toronto.

His next book is Accelerated Minds: Unlocking the Fascinating, Inspiring, and Often Destructive Impulses that Drive the Entrepreneurial Brain(https://sutherlandhousebooks.com/product/accelerated-minds/).
